conclusion: Acceleration is defined as the rate of change of velocity with respect to time, which corresponds to the slope of the v-t graph.
The graph shows the velocity (v) of object B as a function of time (t).
The slope of the v-t graph at any point represents the instantaneous acceleration of object B.
The red tangent lines in the second image indicate the slope at different points on the curve for object B.
At t = 0, the velocity of object B is zero, and the slope of the graph is positive, indicating that object B has a positive acceleration.
As time progresses toward t1, the graph curves downward, and the slope decreases, meaning the acceleration is decreasing during this interval.
At t1, the tangent line becomes horizontal, indicating that the slope is zero and the acceleration is zero at t1.
After t1, the graph starts curving upward, and the slope of the tangent lines begins to increase again, indicating that the acceleration becomes positive and starts increasing.
By t2, the slope of the graph is steep and positive, showing that the acceleration has increased significantly.
From t = 0 to t1, the acceleration of object B decreases and reaches zero at t1.
From t1 to t2, the acceleration of object B increases.
The trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval 0 to t2 is as follows: The acceleration decreases from t = 0 to t1, reaching zero at t1, and then increases from t1 to t2.
